conversation.content: [frozen smile] Marcus? I didn't realize you'd be attending tonight's gala, especially not as the representative from Meridian Industries.
Rebecca, what a pleasant surprise. Yes, I've been handling their charitable giving portfolio for the past three years now. [measured pause] Interesting to see you here in a professional capacity.
Professional capacity is the only capacity I operate in, as I'm sure you can appreciate given our, um, recent interaction at the Fairmont last weekend.
[quietly amused] The wedding was lovely, by the way. Your ex-husband seemed thoroughly convinced we'd been dating for months.
Look, we need to discuss the Q3 projections for your company's advertising spend, and I'd rather not have this particular conflict of interest hanging over the negotiations. [clears throat]
[casually] There's no conflict here, Rebecca. What I do in my personal time and what Meridian does with its marketing budget are completely separate matters.
[lowering voice] Separate? You charged me two thousand dollars to hold my hand and tell my cousin Jennifer about our fake trip to Santorini.
And you got exactly the service you paid forâ€”a convincing performance that saved you from your family's prying questions. [shrugs] Now, about that digital campaign proposal your team sent over.
[tightly controlled] The proposal outlines a twelve-million-dollar integrated strategy that will require multiple high-level meetings between us over the next six months.
[businesslike] Perfect.
[incredulous] Perfect? Marcus, or whatever your actual name is, you realize this means weekly video calls, quarterly presentations to the board, and me vouching for your company's commitment.
My name really is Marcus, and yes, I understand exactly what this entails. I've been successfully managing multi-million dollar accounts while maintaining my other profession for years now.
[resigned sigh] Fine, but we need ground rules. No mentioning the wedding, no clever innuendos during meetings, and absolutely no telling anyone at Meridian about this.
[professionally] Agreed. Though I should mention, your CEO's wife has my other business card. We met at a gallery opening last month.
[barely controlled panic] Sandra knows? Oh God, she's going to see us together at the quarterly review and put two and two together.
[calmly] She's very discreet, and frankly, she's more concerned about the ROI on your proposed campaign than my evening activities. [pause] Besides, she thinks you have excellent taste.
[deflating slightly] This is insane. I'm standing here at a charity gala discussing media buying with someone who literally pretended to be in love with me for money last week.
I prefer to think of it as me being exceptionally good at understanding client needs, whether that's personal companionship or strategic market positioning.
[dry laugh] Well, at least you're consistent with your sales pitch. Tomorrow, nine AM, conference room three, and please wear something that screams 'corporate executive' not 'available for hire.'
[wry smile in voice] Don't worry, Rebecca. I save the Armani for the evening clients. For Meridian, it's strictly Brooks Brothers and spreadsheets.

scenario: An account executive discovers her biggest corporate client at a charity gala is actually the gigolo she hired last week to pose as her boyfriend at her ex-husband's wedding.
